cmCourseInfo.description: History, theory and practice of international development, and current approaches and debates in international development studies. The course explores the evolution of policy and practice in international development and the academic discourses that surround it. Lectures by various faculty and guests will explore the multi-disciplinary nature of international development studies. This course is a prerequisite for all IDS B-level courses.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to International Development Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: This experiential learning course allows students to experience first hand the realities, challenges, and opportunities of working with development organizations in Africa. The goal is to allow students to actively engage in research, decision-making, problem solving, partnership building, and fundraising, processes that are the key elements of development work. Same as AFSA03H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Experiencing Development in Africa

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces students to major development problems, focusing on international economic and political economy factors. Examines trade, aid, international institutions such as the World Bank, the IMF and the WTO. Examines both conventional economic perspectives as well as critiques of these perspectives. This course can be counted for credit in ECM Programs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Political Economy of International Development
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [MGEA01H3/(ECMA01H3) and MGEA05H3/(ECMA05H3)] or [MGEA02H3/(ECMA04H3) and MGEA06H3/(ECMA06H3)] and IDSA01H3

cmCourseInfo.description: The environmental consequences of development activities with emphasis on tropical countries. Environmental change in urban, rainforest, semi-arid, wetland, and mountainous systems. The influences of development on the global environment; species extinction, loss of productive land, reduced access to resources, declining water quality and quantity, and climate change.
cmCourseInfo.title: Development and Environment
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: IDSA01H3 or EESA01H3

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers an introduction to the political, institutional, social, economic, epidemiological, and ideological forces in the field of international/global health. While considerable reference will be made to “high-income” countries, major emphasis will be placed on the health conditions of “low- and middle-income” countries – and their interaction with the development “aid” milieu. After setting the historical and political economy context, the course explores key topics and themes in global health including: international/global health agencies and activities; data on health; epidemiology and the global distribution of health and disease; the societal determinants of health and health equity; health economics and the organization of health care systems in comparative perspective; globalization, trade, work, and health; health humanitarianism in the context of crisis, health and the environment; the ingredients of healthy societies across the world; and social justice approaches to global health.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to International/Global Health
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 5.0 credits including IDSA01H3

courses.name: Equity, Ethics and Justice in International Development

cmCourseInfo.description: What constitutes equitable, ethical as well as socially and environmentally just processes and outcomes of development? This course explores these questions with particular emphasis on their philosophical and ideological foundations and on the challenges of negotiating global differences in cultural, political and environmental values in international development.
cmCourseInfo.title: Equity, Ethics and Justice in International Development
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: IDSA01H3

courses.name: Confronting Developments Racist Past and Present

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers students an in-depth survey of the role race and racism plays in Development of Thought and Practice across the globe. Students will learn the multiple ways colonial imaginaries and classificatory schemes continue to shape International Development and Development Studies. A variety of conceptual frameworks for examining race, racism and racialization will also be introduced.
cmCourseInfo.title: Confronting Development’s Racist Past and Present

courses.name: Political Economy of Knowledge Technology and Development

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines in-depth the roles of information and communication technology (ICT) in knowledge production and their impact on development. Do new forms of social media make communication more effective, equitable, or productive in the globalized world? How has network media changed governance, advocacy, and information flow and knowledge exchange and what do these mean for development?
cmCourseInfo.title: Political Economy of Knowledge Technology and Development
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: IDSA01H3
cmCourseInfo.note: Effective Summer 2013 this course will not be delivered online; instead, it will be delivered as an in-class seminar.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Course Description: How is artificial intelligence shaping us, and who is engineering our futures

AI tools like ChatGPT, Zoom, and Canvas have become everyday platforms, yet they carry hidden assumptions about knowledge, labour, and power that often go unexamined. This course critically explores how AI is reshaping education, economic growth, and global inequality, raising urgent questions around data governance, techno-nationalism, and algorithmic justice and what they mean for development.

We will examine how digital infrastructures determine what counts as knowledge and whose interests they serve. Topics include algorithmic governance, platform capitalism, the geopolitics of AI, and Indigenous approaches to technology and sovereignty. Anchored in global and community contexts, we will explore how diverse groups resist, redesign, and reimagine technological systems.

Through case studies, media analysis, and collaborative mapping, students will explore strategies for asserting individual and collective agency, challenging extractive and inequitable systems, and imagining alternative AI futures grounded in justice, care, and epistemic pluralism.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines research design and methods appropriate to development fieldwork. Provides `hands on' advice (practical, personal and ethical) to those preparing to enter "the field"; or pursuing development work as a career. Students will prepare a research proposal as their main course assignment.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Design for Development Fieldwork
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [9.0 credits including: IDSA01H3 and IDSB07H3] and [at least 6.0 credits satisfying Specialist Co-op Program in International Development Studies Requirements 1 through 4]
cmCourseInfo.note: Limited to students enrolled in the Specialist (Co-op) Program in IDS. Students in other IDS programs may be admitted with permission of instructor subject to the availability of spaces.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Permission of instructor is required. You may select this course but will not be officially enrolled until approved.
Check your status through ACORN to see whether you have been approved.

courses.name: Contemporary Africa: State, Society, and Politics

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is intended as an advanced critical introduction to contemporary African politics. It seeks to examine the nature of power and politics, state and society, war and violence, epistemology and ethics, identity and subjectivities, history and the present from a comparative and historical perspective. It asks what the main drivers of African politics are, and how we account for political organization and change on the continent from a comparative and historical perspective. Same as AFSC03H3.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary Africa: State, Society, and Politics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [IDSA01H3 or AFSA01H3] or by instructor’s permission

cmCourseInfo.description: Studies the phases of the project management cycle with emphasis on situational analysis and identification of needs, project implementation, project monitoring and evaluation. Examines basic organizational development, the role of Canadian non-governmental organizations engaged in the delivery of development assistance as well as with CIDA's policies and practices.
cmCourseInfo.title: Project Management I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: IDSA01H3 and [1.0 credit at the B-level in IDS courses]
cmCourseInfo.note: Restricted to students in the IDS Specialist and Major programs.

cmCourseInfo.description: Critical perspectives on the effects of traditional and 'new' media on development policy and practice. The course examines the increasingly significant role the media plays in the development process, the ways in which media-generated images of development and developing countries affect development policy and the potential of 'new' media for those who are marginalized from the development process.
cmCourseInfo.title: Media and Development
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: IDSA01H3 and IDSB10H3

courses.name: State Formation and the Politics of Development in the Global South: Explaining Divergent Outcomes

cmCourseInfo.description: The state has proven to be one of the key factors paving the way for some countries in the Global South to escape conditions of underdevelopment and launch successful development programs over time. But, why have effective states emerged in some countries in the Global South and not in others? This course seeks to answer this question by investigating processes of "state formation" using a comparative historical approach. The course will begin by introducing students to theories of state formation. These theories will raise important questions about state formation processes that include: What is a modern, "rational-legal" state in theory? What do states look like in practice? What is state capacity and what are its components? What is the infrastructural power of the state and how does it differ from the despotic power of a state? How do state efforts to extend infrastructural power ignite political battles for social control at both elite and popular sector levels of society? Finally, how do processes of state formation unfold over time? The course, then, dives into comparative examinations of state formation using examples from across the Global South – from Central and South America to Africa, the Middle East, South Asia, and East Asia.
cmCourseInfo.title: State Formation and the Politics of Development in the Global South: Explaining Divergent Outcomes
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: IDSA01H3 or POLB90H3
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: IDSC10H3 if taken in Winter 2023; POLC90H3 if taken in Winter 2018, Winter 2019, Winter 2020, Winter 2021.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines how institutions and power relations shape the production and distribution of food, particularly in the global South. The course evaluates competing theories of hunger and malnutrition. It also explores the historical evolution of contemporary food provisioning and evaluates the viability and development potential of alternative food practices.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Political Economy of Food
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: IDSB01H3 or [FSTA01H3 and FSTB01H3]

sections.name: LEC01
sections.subTitle: Critical Approaches to Studying Youth and Children in International Development

cmCourseInfo.description: The topics presented in this course will represent a range of issues in international development studies. Topics will vary by instructor and term.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in International Development Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 10.0 credits including IDSA01H3

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content: Course Description: This interdisciplinary course examines key concepts, theories, and ideas around youth and children in international development. We will consider the ways in which youth and children’s lived experiences are often shaped by social, political, and economic factors outside of their own control as well as the different social locations in which they are situated. In this course, race, gender, sex, class, and disability will all be relevant in exploring questions of both the rights of children and youth as well as ethical responsibilities to them at global and local levels. We will also examine how personhood has been defined historically, and the way its meaning has changed over time to shape the lives of children and youth. As part of this course, students will learn how the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) attend to the specific issues shaping the development and well-being of youth and children. This course will run as a seminar with interactive lectures, class discussions, audiovisual technologies, and case studies. Class materials will draw from research articles, social media, online resources, blogs, and print media, to center the lives of youth and children in the context of international development.

courses.name: Populism, Development, and Globalization in the Global South

sections.name: LEC01
sections.subTitle: Populism, North and South, and the Changing World Order

cmCourseInfo.description: The rise of populism has been widespread and often linked to processes of economic globalization. This course explores the historical and more recent economic and social factors shaping populist movements and leaderships in the Global South.
cmCourseInfo.title: Populism, Development, and Globalization in the Global South
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: IDSA01H3 or POLB90H3

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content: Course Description: This course examines the emergence of movements and regimes labelled as ?populist,? with particular attention to the differing impacts of economic globalization on the social, economic and political conditions of countries of the Global South and Global North. The course draws attention to the substantive differences among cases and their impacts, raising the question of the usefulness of the populist label.  Case studies include Trump (US), Bolsonaro (Brazil), Chavez (Venezuela), and Modi (India).

courses.name: Development, Citizen Action and Social Change in the Global South

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores the question of citizenship through theories of citizen participation and action in dialogue with a wide range of recent empirical case studies from the global south. Going beyond formal rights and status, the course looks at deeper forms of political inclusion and direct participation in decision-making on political and policy issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Development, Citizen Action and Social Change in the Global South
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: IDSA01H3 and [1.0 credit at the B-level in IDS courses]

courses.name: New Paradigms in Development: The Role of Emerging Powers

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the growing role of the emerging powers - the BRICS countries grouping of Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa - in international development. The course examines recent development initiatives by these actors in Africa, Latin America and Asia. It also explores the question of whether BRICS-led development programs and practices challenge the top-down, expert led stances of past development interventions – from colonialism to the western aid era.
cmCourseInfo.title: New Paradigms in Development: The Role of Emerging Powers
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: IDSA01H3 and [1.0 credit at the B-level in IDS courses]

courses.name: Community-driven Development: Cooperatives, Social Enterprises and the Black Social Economy

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to alternative business institutions (including cooperatives, credit unions, worker-owned firms, mutual aid, and social enterprises) to challenge development. It investigates the history and theories of the solidarity economy as well as its potential contributions to local, regional and international socio-economic development. There will be strong experiential education aspects in the course to debate issues. Students analyze case studies with attention paid to Africa and its diaspora to combat exclusion through cooperative structures. Same as AFSC19H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Community-Driven Development: Cooperatives, Social Enterprises and the Black Social Economy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: AFSA01H3 or IDSA01H3 or POLB90H3 or permission of the instructor

cmCourseInfo.description: The rise of both political and climate instability across the world has led to global instability and conflict. Millions have been displaced by wars that have erupted across and within national borders. In the Sudan, Ukraine and Gaza, entire communities have been forced to flee their homes as a result of military conflict. The climate crisis is linked to, and will continue to intersect with, such conflict. Climate migration, precipitated by extreme weather events, highlights the need for transformative responses to humanitarian crises. These conflicts are increasingly posing new challenges for globally “just” approaches to humanitarian aid (Redfield, 2020), food insecurity (Wingfield, 2024), human rights and gender violence. In this course, students will collaborate with students from South Africa and Sweden, and engage with leading academics, civil society leaders and activists to learn more about new approaches to global justice through a humanitarian lens. Drawing from insights from a global learning project named the Global Classroom for Democracy Innovation, students will engage in a learning environment which is designed around international and intercultural engagement, to work on and co-design around "borderless" problems. Questions around the widespread undermining and erosion of democracy, and (inter)national responses to increasing humanitarian crises, will be at the center of student engagements, allowing them to think from particular localities while also working across local/national/planetary scales.
cmCourseInfo.title: Humanitarian Aid and Global Development
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: IDSA01H3

cmCourseInfo.description: Normal enrolment in this course will be made up of IDS students who have completed their work placement. Each student will give at least one seminar dealing with their research project and/or placement. The research paper will be the major written requirement for the course, to be submitted no later than mid-March. The course will also include seminars by practicing professionals on a variety of development topics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Post-placement Seminar and Thesis
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: IDSA01H3 and students must have completed the first four years of the IDS Specialist Co-op Program or its equivalent and have completed their placement. Also, permission of the instructor is required.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Permission of instructor is required. You may select this course but will not be officially enrolled until approved.
Check your status through ACORN to see whether you have been approved.

courses.name: Advanced Research Seminar in Critical Development Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced seminar in critical development studies with an emphasis on perspectives and theories from the global South. The main purpose of the course is to help prepare students theoretically and methodologically for the writing of a major research paper based on secondary data collection. The theoretical focus on the course will depend on the interests of the faculty member teaching it.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Research Seminar in Critical Development Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14.0 credits including IDSC04H3
cmCourseInfo.note: Restricted to students in the Specialist (non Co-op) Programs in IDS. If space is available, students from the Major Program in IDS may gain admission with the permission of the instructor.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content: Restricted to students in the non co-op IDS Specialist programs. You may select this course but will not be officially enrolled until approved. Check your status through ACORN to see whether you have been approved. If space is available, students from the IDS Major program may gain admission with the permission of the instructor.

courses.name: Feminist and Postcolonial Perspectives in Development Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: This interdisciplinary course traces the advance of feminist and postcolonial thinking in development studies. The course serves as a capstone experience for IDS students and social science majors looking to fully engage with feminist and postcolonial theories of development. This course combines short lectures with student led-discussions and critical analyses of development thought and practice.
cmCourseInfo.title: Feminist and Postcolonial Perspectives in Development Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 12.0 credits

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines resource extraction in African history. We examine global trade networks in precolonial Africa, and the transformations brought by colonial extractive economies. Case studies, from diamonds to uranium, demonstrate how the resource curse has affected states and economies, especially in the postcolonial period. Same as AFSD07H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Extractive Industries in Africa
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [10.0 credits including [AFSA01H3 or IDSA01H3 or POLB90H3]] or permission of instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content: Course Description: This interdisciplinary course examines the complex colonial power relations in Africa that govern extractive industries, from a development perspective. It will explore how global trade and economies as well as both state and non-state actors have engaged in industrial extraction of the Continent’s natural resources throughout the precolonial, colonial, and post-independence periods. The extraction of natural resources such as cocoa, oil, diamonds, rubber, and minerals by large multinational corporations, resulting in a commodity-driven mode of production that overlooks the human, social, political, and environmental cost to Africa, will be discussed. Topics will be presented through interactive lectures, class discussions, audiovisual technologies, and case studies.

courses.name: Community-Centered Media Tactics for Development Advocacy and Social

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the intersection of community-centered research, art, media, politics, activism and how they intertwine with grass-root social change strategies. Students will learn about the multiple forms of media tactics, including alternative and tactical media (fusion of art, media, and activism) that are being used by individuals and grass-root organizations to promote public debate and advocate for changes in development-related public policies. Through case studies, hands-on workshops, community-led learning events, and a capstone project in collaboration with community organizations, students will gain practical research, media and advocacy skills in formulating and implementing strategies for mobilizing public support for social change.
cmCourseInfo.title: Community-Centered Media Tactics for Development Advocacy and Social Change
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: IDSA01H3 and [1.0 credit in C-level IDS courses] and [0.5 credit in D-level IDS courses]
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: IDSD10H3 (if taken in the Winter 2018, 2019, 2020 or 2021 sessions)

cmCourseInfo.description: The topics presented in this course will represent a range of issues in international development studies. Topics will vary by instructor and term.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in International Development Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 12.0 credits, including IDSA01H3

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Topic for Fall 2025: Contextualizing the Resource Curse: Coloniality, Violence and Dignity Taking in the Rush for African Minerals
Course Description: Also known as the ‘paradox of plenty’, the resource curse refers to the paradox that many Global South countries and regions with an abundance of non-renewable natural resources (e.g. mineral and fuels), tend to have less economic growth and worse development outcomes than countries with fewer natural resources. While poor technology, poor governance and economic policies, among other things, are often blamed for this phenomenon, it has become clear that coloniality, along with violence and dignity taking associated with it, looms large in mineral rich, yet economically poor  African countries. Using African cases of resource curse, which is often accompanied by extreme poverty and violence, this topics course explores reasons why the legacy of colonial conquest and current ‘naked’ imperialism should be seen as the real causes of the resource curse and armed conflicts in these African countries.

cmCourseInfo.description: The topics presented in this course will represent a range of issues in international development studies. Topics will vary by instructor and term.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in International Development Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 12.0 credits, including IDSA01H3

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Topic of Winter 2026: Philanthrocapitalism and Development

Course Description:   In recent months development funding has been radically transformed with catastrophic consequences for development practice and the lives of vulnerable people around the world.  While shocking, the staging of this transformation has been building for years. Over the past two decades, modes of funding international development have changed significantly. Aid and development funding has always been political, tied to the ideological and material priorities of donor nations and their foreign policy objectives, as well as to the aspirations of those working within and directing the activities of development agencies.  However, over the last two decades, international development has been increasingly financed and implemented by a nexus of billionaires and corporate foundations. From the Gates Foundation’s ‘new’ green revolution in Africa, to the Clinton Foundation’s engagement in the Global Fund, both the capital and the goals that structure development policy and practice internationally have been shaped by the interests of the wealthy and the associated tools of celebrity humanitarianism and corporate social responsibility.  The role of the wealthy in international development, however, is not a new phenomenon.  The act of moral cleansing through the provision of public infrastructure and reformist social policy by 19th century robber barons and industrialists like Andrew Carnegie, the Rockefellers or the Vanderbilts in North America, presage what we see on the global stage today.


In this course, we will examine the recent rise of philanthrocapitalism, and its explicit ties to, and intersections with, the intensification of global capitalism, personal wealth, political influence, and development policy and practice.  We will evaluate the political opportunities that facilitate a role for corporate capital and private wealth in development practice and consider the range of impacts that this increasing role of transnational wealth plays in shaping the futures of people around the globe.

cmCourseInfo.description: The goal of the course is for students to examine in a more extensive fashion the academic literature on a particular topic in International Development Studies not covered by existing course offering. Courses will normally only be available to students in their final year of study at UTSC. It is the student's responsibility to find a faculty member who is willing to supervise the course, and the students must obtain consent from the supervising instructor and from the Chair/Associate Chair of the Department of Global Development Studies before registering for this course.
cmCourseInfo.title: Directed Reading
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 12.0 credits, including IDSA01H3 and permission of the instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
SUPERVISED STUDY/RESEARCH & INDEPENDENT STUDY COURSES
Step 1: Request the course on ACORN. Your status will be INT. You will not be officially enrolled until you complete the remaining steps (below).
Step 2: Meet with the Supervisor and obtain their signature on a 'Supervised Study form'. Make sure the course code, supervisor name and title of the project is clearly printed on the form as this information will appear on your transcript. The Supervised Study form is available at: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/registrar/supervised-study-form. Your Department listed below may require additional paperwork. Students should contact the Office listed for more information.
Step 3: Submit the signed Supervised Study form by email to Arifa Nitol arifa.nitol@utoronto.ca.
The Department will update your course status on ACORN from interim (INT) to approved (APP).
Global Development Office HL226

Courses will normally only be available to students in their final year of study at UTSC. It is the student's responsibility to find a faculty member who is willing to supervise the course, and the students must obtain consent from the supervising instructor and from the Chair/Associate Chair of the Department of Global Development Studies before registering for this course.

Global Development Office HL226

cmCourseInfo.description: The goal of the course is for students to prepare and write a senior undergraduate research paper in International Development Studies. For upper-level students whose interests are not covered in one of the other courses normally offered. Courses will normally only be available to students in their final year of study at UTSC. It is the student's responsibility to find a faculty member who is willing to supervise the course, and the students must obtain consent from the supervising instructor and from the Chair/Associate Chair of the Department of Global Development Studies before registering for this course.
cmCourseInfo.title: Directed Research
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 12.0 credits including IDSA01H3 and permission of the instructor

Global Development Office HL226

courses.name: The Role of Researcher-Practitioner Engagement in Development

sections.name: LEC01
sections.subTitle: Community-based Participatory Research for Global Development

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on recent theories and approaches to researcher-practitioner engagement in development. Using case studies, interviews, and extensive literature review, students will explore whether such engagements offer opportunities for effective social change and improved theory.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Role of Researcher-Practitioner Engagement in Development
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 12.0 credits, including IDSA01H3

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content: Course Description: This course focuses on training students in community-based participatory research. This course is designed in partnership with the Toronto-based non-profit organization Volunteer Toronto (https://www.volunteertoronto.ca). Students will participate in a research project for Volunteer Toronto. Throughout the course students will explore whether community-based participatory research offers opportunities for effective social change.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers an advanced critical introduction to the security-development nexus and the political economy of conflict, security, and development. It explores the major issues in contemporary conflicts, the securitization of development, the transformation of the security and development landscapes, and the broader implications they have for peace and development in the Global South. Same as AFSD20H3.
cmCourseInfo.title: Thinking Conflict, Security, and Development
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [12.0 including (IDSA01H3 or AFSA01H3 or POLC09H3)] or by instructor’s permission

courses.name: Public Policy and Human Development in the Global South

cmCourseInfo.description: While domestic and international political factors have discouraged pro human development public policies in much of the global south, there have been some important success stories. This course examines the economic and social policies most successful in contributing to human development and explores the reasons behind these rare cases of relatively successful human development. Same as POLD90H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Public Policy and Human Development in the Global South
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [1.0 credit from: IDSB01H3, IDSB04H3, IDSB06H3, POLB90H3 or POLB91H3] and [2.0 credits at the C-level in any courses]
